title: Not Quite Myriad, Not Quite Frutiger....
content:
As you can see, the ’$’, ’y’, and ’9’ are a much closer match to Myriad Pro. However, the ’M’ (which has straight sides) is a better match to Frutiger. What, in fact, is the original?

Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091026193841im_/http:/typophile.com/files/test_6254.jpg)
author: Fontophile

comments.content: If it isn’t Frutiger nor Myriad it could be Segoe.

hrm.. I was going to say: Akzidenz-Grotesk  
but the $ is not identical
IMHO that is Myriad. The minor differences appear to be due to the reproduction
Most of it is a match to Myriad but the “M” is clearly different.

I guess you can see why there was such a ruckus a few years ago when Myriad came out.

ChrisL

I looked at [Segoe TV](http://web.archive.org/web/20091026193841/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ascender/segoe-tv/), if that’s the one you meant Jan, and it seems closer to Frutiger than Myriad.

I was thinking I recently saw a new sans with a Myriad-like y, but can’t think where I saw it.

- Mike Yanega

Another thought: wasn’t there a MM version of Myriad? Is it possible older versions, or MM interpolations, had slightly different details than the current OT versions from Adobe?

- Mike Yanega

No, I didn’t mean Segoe TV but Segoe UI or whatever. Couldn’t find a specimen anywhere to check. Ascender doesn’t provide one for whatever reason. From what I’ve seen at least the ‘M’ in Segoe has vertical stems.

_Another thought: wasn’t there a MM version of Myriad? Is it possible older versions, or MM interpolations, had slightly different details than the current OT versions from Adobe?\>_

Hey Mike, good thought but it looks like MM still has the tilted “M” characters.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091026193841im_/http:/typophile.com/files/myriadMM_5610.jpg)
I certainly remember using Myriad MM back in the day... I’ll try to find it for comparison.

or what about **ps Ratio** by Mark Caneso

[http://cargocollective.com/pstype#39674](http://web.archive.org/web/20091026193841/http:/cargocollective.com/pstype#39674 "http://cargocollective.com/pstype#39674")
Wasn’t there an Apple-only version of Myriad? Maybe that had a different M?

the **M** loox a little like ITC Franklin at FontBureau

[http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/ITCFranklin/styles](http://web.archive.org/web/20091026193841/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/ITCFranklin/styles "http://www.fontbureau.com/fonts/ITCFranklin/styles")

the **$** is the same... but not the letters **a y**

could it be they only changed the M (for some reason)?
